column4: After installing the latest kernel (.11) my X crashes. I'm pretty sure it's b/c my nVidia driver is not for the current kernel, but nvidia-glx says it's up to date. What gives?
you installed nvidia-glx from an external repository, didn't you?
Yes I'm using the beta driver from albertmilone.com. However, I installed via repo, so I would have expected it to update?
if it has been updated... are you sure it has?
!nvidia9 | lmosher, these ones are updated anyway
I'll try that repo. If the driver hasn't been updated, why is it still crashing X on the new kernel? Oh it's probably the restricted modules
hm? if it *hasn't* been updated, then it's normal that X won't start
though it shouldn't "crash", it should just refuse to start
Yeah my terminology is incorrect, it just won't start. So basically if it hasn't updated (I'm checking that repo now) then I'll just need to wait until there is a new version?
yes. that's the flip side of using third-party repositories...
even the ones i've given above weren't updated during the first couple of days after the kernel update
yeah :/ Ohwell I can deal it's not like the new kernel had any changes I actually would notice.
keep in mind that, when the kernel gets an update, you can always still boot the old one
!es | nchmilo
Hrm ok it is installing a new version of the linux restricted modules, so that might fix the driver, or no? There isn't an updated version of nvidia-glx...
it'll probably work, yes
Cool thanks.

Another question regarding kernel updates: Why does it re-set my grub menu list? I've organized it the way I like (i.e. my generic kernel first, then windows XP). After an update it deletes my windows listing. I'd rather is just add the new kernel options :/
hm, yeah, it does that
not sure there's any workaround (besides making a backup)
Ok, I can deal, I wasn't sure if I was doing something wrong in my menu.lst that made it get reset. It's no big deal it's just a little annoyance every time I update a kernel.
